text: Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like- Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything.

text: Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. But I do know that it’s not that effective. It just prolongs it to give me like like an additional, like you said three to five years. But with that, is there any other method of uh treatment that we could look into that would do more of um eradicating the cancer, in a sense? I know the hormonal is going to be the next - that’s the next logical- Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: piece to do. But is there anything there as far as treatment that we could look at that - to sort of get rid of the cancer? Do you understand what I’m saying? I I know. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, of course, that always should be the goal. No, there’s nothing that I, that I can think or that that I um can recommend that that will have a high chance of curing the cancer.

text: Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it? Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. text: Patient: Every time I go in… Doctor: You just go and get your injection? Patient: Yeah and I think it would be better off do everything here. Doctor: Okay. Well I’m just wondering then if we should hold off and uh because we may have to switch him to Firmagon if he’s not getting enough suppression. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Okay so why don’t you hold off on the injection tomorrow. Patient: Don’t take it tomorrow? Doctor: Don’t take it tomorrow. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see what your testosterone level is and I’m going to put in for a different injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately that means it’ll have to be a monthly shot, but you know we may have to do that if your testosterone is not suppressed. Because if the Lupron is not working for you…

text: Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to.

text: Family Member: You do?! Doctor: Yeah, yeah, we do zap. Yeah. Family Member: My creativity works dear. Doctor: There are several things going on at once, zapping one or two won't slow down anything. We only zap-. So here's the scenario when we would do that, okay. Okay. We give you the stuff and you're, you're on cruise control with Xtandi and your PSA is zero and looking great. And every time we scan you only have two of these spots in your ribs that just won't go away. Family Member: Light up. Doctor: So then we radiate those two and then see if we can just keep them longer. Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. text: Family Member: To do the tests honey. Doctor: Yeah to do the testing and to do the… Family Member: Is this the long day. Is the first day the long day? Doctor: Oh no, no that’s not treatment day. It’s just pre – all of the screening and testing will happen that day. Family Member: So what would that – that’s an echo and what else? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
